The History of Rock, Paper, Scissors

Rock, Paper, Scissors is a simple hand game that is often used as a selection method similar to coin flipping or drawing straws. It is a zero-sum game with three possible outcomes: a tie, a win, or a loss. The origins of the game can be traced back to ancient China and Japan.

Origins in Ancient China

The earliest known version of the game is thought to have originated in China, during the Han Dynasty (206 BCE – 220 CE), where it was known as "shoushiling" (手势令). The game was later introduced to Japan and became known as "jan-ken." The Japanese version uses the same hand-gestures but the words for the gestures are different.

Spread to the West

The game spread to the West during the early 20th century and became known as "Rock, Paper, Scissors." It quickly gained popularity due to its simple rules and the fact that it requires no equipment, making it accessible to people of all ages and cultures.

Modern Usage

Today, Rock, Paper, Scissors is played worldwide and is often used in decision-making scenarios. It has also been the subject of mathematical research and competitive tournaments.
